The chlorine system has a group of pressure sensors and gas detector alarms that will send an alarm to the supervisor in charge at the Control Room.There are also audible alarms locally.A wind sock is installed over the building housing the chlorine containers.

We have had Manatee County's Emergency Management Department model a worst case release for this plant.This release was based on a total of 2000 pounds bing released at a rate of 200 pounds per minute.The release took just 10 minutes.The wind speed was 8.3 miles per hour.The plant is located at the Manatee Reservoir which is a rural area now but is rapidly developing as is the rest of the County.

The Cameo model predicted the plume would extend .6 miles,just over one half mile.In this area, are about 25 residential homes.Also there is a Florida State Park and a Sheriffs Boys Ranch that is in the affected area.Chlorine is heavier than air and would travel close tro the ground.In high concentrations it can suffocate.It would affect humans,animals and plant life.

There are chlorine alarm sensors in the storage area that will send an alarm to the Operations Staff if the chlorine in the air goes over 1 part per million.

Because of the necessity of responding quickly to a release,we have trained the Operatons Staff to be able to respond.We have supplied them with self-contained air masks and emergency repair kits.A notification procedure has also been set up through the 911 system.

The supervisor responding to the alarm will call the other two operators on shift by radio of a chlorine leak.Both of the operators will put on a self-contained breathing apparatus(SCBA) and go to the chlorine storage area to assess the leak.The operators will notify the supervisor in charge of the situation.

Depending on the degree of the leak,it will be either stopped using a one ton 'B' emergency kit or if it can't be controlled, the supervisor in charge will notify all plant personnel to evacuate

the plant over the P.A. system.He will then begin notifying the proper authorities of the emergency according to Secton 304 SARA Title lll.

The Braden River Fire Department would be one of the first responders.They are completely familiar with the facility and have conducted many safety classes here at the plant.

A totally enclosed storage building with a chlorine scrubber or another disinfectant source is currently planned as a future safety improvement.

The Risk Management Plan(RMP) was developed to comply with the Clean Air Act R112(CAA) which takes effect on June 21,1999. The act requires all industrial plants that have extremely hazardous chemicals over the threshold limit to have a plan that addresses the safe handling and use of these chemicals. This plan is to be provided to all local,state,and federal regulatory agencies. The immediate neighbors of these industrial plants would then have access to these plans and be aware of what could happen if an industrial spill occurred. The Acts intent was to make the users of these chemicals more aware of the safe handling and use through planning. It also wanted the neighbors to be aware and provide input to these plans so they would feel safer living next to these plants.

Hazardous Release Scenario
Manatee County Water Treatment Plant is a conventional water plant that provides coagulation,settling and disenfection for treatment. Chlorine and Ammonia are used during treatment and are considered extremely hazardous. Only chlorine is stored on-site over the reportable threshold(Section 304 of SARA Title lll).

Normally,there are full and empty one-ton chlorine containers in an open sided building at the southwest side of the plant. A maximum of 20 one-ton containers are kept. The delivery system is designed to operate with a minimum chance of a accidental release.The tanks in use are positioned in a 'U' shape fashion,three one-ton containers on each arm of the 'U'.
